sn47.51-62:0.3: Twelve Discourses on the Ganges River, Etc.
sn47.51-62:1.1: “Mendicants, the Ganges river slants, slopes, and inclines to the east.
sn47.51-62:1.2: In the same way, a mendicant who develops and cultivates the four kinds of mindfulness meditation slants, slopes, and inclines to extinguishment.
sn47.51-62:2.1: And how does a mendicant who develops the four kinds of mindfulness meditation slant, slope, and incline to extinguishment?
sn47.51-62:2.2: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.51-62:2.3: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …
sn47.51-62:2.5: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.51-62:2.6: That’s how a mendicant who develops and cultivates the four kinds of mindfulness meditation slants, slopes, and inclines to extinguishment.”
sn47.51-62:2.7: (To be expanded for each of the different rivers as in SN 45.91–102.)
sn47.51-62:3.1: Six on slanting to the east,
sn47.51-62:3.2: and six on slanting to the ocean;
sn47.51-62:3.4: and that’s how this chapter is recited.
